com.camerontec.catalys.core.session.persistence

Interface IFIXSessionStatePersister

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    JournalingPersister, MemoryPersister, MemorySeqNoOnlyPersister

    public interface IFIXSessionStatePersister
    This interface defines how a session persists FIX messages (outbound and, optionally, inbound) and session state using any generic persistence mechanism. Catalys provides a number of implementations of this interface.

    IFIXSessionStatePersister implementations can store and recover any class of message that implements the IFIXMessage interface. In order to be able to recover different classes of messages, the persister needs to know how to create those messages. Per default persisters get the message factories from their FIX sessions.

    In addition to implementing the methods in this interface, each IFIXSessionStatePersister class should provide two constructors:

    1) A default constructor which is needed to create persister objects "on-the-fly" using reflection via JMX configuration.

    2) A constructor which takes a single Properties object as a parameter.

    For example, 

     public MyPersister( Properties properties );

    This constructor is used create persister objects from configuration data.

    Usage:
    Persister object methods are called by the core Catalys code as follows:

    • persistOutMessage - called just before the write to the FIX connection.
    • persistInMessage - called when a message has been received and delivered to the session for processing. Persisting inbound messages is optional.
    • persistInMsgSeqNum - called when corresponding message has been received and processed.
    • persistInMsgSeqNum - also called, with parameter 0, when sequence numbers are reset.
    • clearOutMessages - called when sequence numbers are reset.
    • clearInMessages - called when sequence numbers are reset.

    Note:
    While this interface provides a method persistInMessage(IFIXMessage) to persist input messages, implementations should actually only persist input messages if isPersistInMessages() returns true. In most cases persisting input messages is unnecessary, inefficient and incorrect for the following reasons:

    • unnecessary - The FIX protocol provides a mechanism to rerequest messages for recovery purposes.
    • inefficient - Persisting messages is usually the performance bottleneck in any FIX engine so it should be avoided if unnecessary.
    • incorrect - Most importantly, this is not correct. To quote from the FIX specification section describing the ResendRequest. "...the sending application may wish to consider the message type when resending messages; e.g. if a new order is in the resend series and a significant time period has elapsed since its original inception, the sender may not wish to retransmit the order given the potential for changed market conditions." In other words, the sending application should be given the opportunity to decide whether a message should be resent or not. Catalys supports this by means of the overridable ISessionCustomizer.shouldResend(java.lang.Object, com.camerontec.catalys.core.message.IFIXMessage) method.

    It is, however, important that the FIX engine persists the sequence number of the last processed message. This is performed by persistInMsgSeqNum(int).

      • getPersistedInMsgSeqNum

        int getPersistedInMsgSeqNum()
                     throws IOException
        Retrieves last persisted inbound FIX message sequence number.
        Returns:
        Last persisted FIX message inbound sequence number, or -1 if none.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs when accessing persisted data.

      • isPersistOutMessages

        boolean isPersistOutMessages()
        Return whether complete outbound FIX messages are being persisted.
        Returns:
        True if complete outbound FIX messages are being persisted, false otherwise.

      • persistOutMessage

        void persistOutMessage(IFIXMessage message)
                throws IOException
        Persist the given outgoing message.

        Note that because the output message contains the output MsgSeqNum, this also has the side effect of persisting the OutMsgSeqNum. This is why this interface does not have an persistOutMsgSeqNum method.

        Note that a persister should not store references to messages in memory since message objects may be reused. Messages should be serialized onto some persistent storage or, if you want to store in memory, a copy of the message should be stored.

        If the sequence number of the message is less than the next expected sequence number the persister's store of out messages is truncated. Previously persisted messages with a sequence number equal to or greater than the sequence number of the newly persisted message are lost and can not be recovered.

        Parameters:
        message - Message to persist
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs when persisting.

      • getPersistedOutMsgSeqNum

        int getPersistedOutMsgSeqNum()
                      throws IOException
        Retrieves MsgSeqNum of last saved output message.
        Returns:
        Last OutMsgSeqNum. -1 if none.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs when accessing persisted data.

      • getOutMessages

        List<IFIXMessage> getOutMessages(int beginSeq,
                                 int endSeq)
                          throws IOException
        Recover all messages that have been sent with sequence numbers between the given limits (inclusive).

        The sequence numbers use the FIX 4.2 convention of 0 for SEQ_NUMBER_INFINITY.

        Parameters:
        beginSeq - Sequence number to start from
        endSeq - Sequence number to end with
        Returns:
        List of all messages between two sequence numbers, or empty list, if none found.
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs when accessing persisted data.
        See Also:
        FIXSequenceNumberConstants.SEQ_NUMBER_INFINITY

      • clearOutMessages

        void clearOutMessages()
               throws IOException
        Clear all messages that have been sent that are not needed any more - for example, when sequence numbers are reset.

        Note that because the last output message number is deduced from the list of output messages, this has the effect of making OutMsgSeqNum -1. In other words, immediately after this method has been called getPersistedOutMsgSeqNum() should return -1.

        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs when accessing persisted data.

      • getToFIXMessageFactory

        IFIXMessageFactory getToFIXMessageFactory()
        Returns the factory used for creating outbound messages recovered from persisted storage.

        For backward compatibility purposes, unless set via setToFIXMessageFactory(IFIXMessageFactory), the standard DefaultToFIXMessageFactory is used.

        Returns:
        The persister's message factory to recreate outbound message objects recovered from from persisted storage.
        See Also:
        setToFIXMessageFactory(IFIXMessageFactory)

      • setToFIXMessageFactory

        void setToFIXMessageFactory(IFIXMessageFactory messageFactory)
        Specifies the factory to be used for creating outbound messages recovered from persisted storage.
        Parameters:
        messageFactory - Factory used to create recovered outbound messages. Ignored if null.
        See Also:
        getToFIXMessageFactory()

      • close

        void close()
    throws IOException
        Close any resources associated with this persister.

        Attempts to use the persister after it is closed will result in undefined behaviour.

        Throws:
        IOException - Error attempting to close any underlying resource.

      • persistInMessage

        void persistInMessage(IFIXMessage message)
               throws IOException
        Persist the given inbound FIX message.

        Note that a persister should not store references to messages in memory since message objects may be reused. Messages should be serialized onto some persistent storage or, if you want to store in memory, a copy of the message should be stored.

        Parameters:
        message - Message to persist
        Throws:
        IOException - if an I/O error occurs when persisting.
